posts.name: Caleb
posts.cooked:
Team 2052 KnightKrawler is excited to be part of the Alpha testing group for the future robot controller SystemCore! This thread will be where we record our progress and experiences. We will also be contributing to the Github discussions on the SystemCoreTesting Repository (here’s a post with some photos of SystemCore on our 2025 bot)

6/26 Meeting Today we flashed SystemCore and installed it onto Mayfly, our 2025 Reefscape robot. The process was decently smooth for an alpha test. Mayfly utilizes the CTRE swerve generator for swerve code, so we had to install a few packages to get the CANivore to work. We have yet to get the on-board CAN busses properly working, so our superstructure wasn’t running today.

Here is a video of Mayfly driving around running on SystemCore:

Please reply with any questions or comments, we’re here to share!

link_counts.title: Show up your robots! · wpilibsuite/SystemCoreTesting · Discussion #3 · GitHub

posts.name: MrRoboSteve
posts.cooked: Do you have a test plan for the new controller?

posts.name: Caleb
posts.cooked: Our next step is to get all mechanisms functioning. Throughout the rest of the summer we will be experimenting to find what pain-points or limits there are. In the fall we will be attending a couple offseason events to run SystemCore through full days of match play.

posts.name: MrRoboSteve
posts.cooked: Will likely be at one of the offseason events you attend. Looking forward to seeing what you find.

posts.name: Tyler
posts.cooked: I look forward to seeing Mayfly with the SystemCore at MRI and RISE!

posts.name: Caleb
posts.cooked:
Apologies for the lack of updates! Due to not having access to our space for a week and summer trips for some members, we just got back to further testing.

7/17 Meeting We updated the SystemCore to the new alpha version along with a couple other vendor updates and fixes.

For some background, our swerve, elevator motors, and climber motors are on the CANivore (all the motors that are low in the bellypan). The devices that are on the elevator carriage and the ground intake are on the RoboRio/SystemCore loop.

Previously we were unable to get the on-board SystemCore CAN loops to consistently connect. The devices on the loop had been getting stuck in the bootloader seemingly at random times and required us to power cycle the bot to fix. We couldn’t find a repeatable process to reproduce this problem. After adding ferrules to the CAN terminations, double checking wiring, and finagling with firmware updates we haven’t seen the issue again yet. We will stress test this further when we have some driver practice next week.

Initial Superstructure Test:

Algae Pickup:

Coral Pickup and Scoring:

Next Steps: If you watched that last video, you could probably tell there isn’t any auto align… So our next goals are to implement our limelight data and wheel odometery. We hope to test how fast we can run our odometry with a full set of subsystems running as well. We are also working on getting our beam breaks working with the SmartIO and the new pulldown resistor (post coming soon around this issue).

posts.name: Caleb
posts.cooked:
calebfynewever:

you could probably tell there isn’t any auto align

7/21 Meeting

Quick Update: After fixing some ip addresses and some debugging, auto-align now works:

Our beam breaks now also are using AnalogInput instead of DigitalInput to avoid some pulldown resistor stuff that @Kevin_Nguyen will detail in a later post

We have driver practice later this week to prepare for offseason events, but next steps are likely testing odometry frequencies and the built-in IMU

posts.name: Kevin Nguyen
posts.cooked:
The SystemCore integration process has been heavy on programming, so I haven’t had enough material to create an update on the mechanical side…until now!

Setting up the SystemCore was simple and fairly self explanatory—we were able to get the board labeled and wired in 10-20 minutes! The documentation is detailed enough and easy to read, so a plus to SystemCore.

Here are some initial thoughts I had when I took a look at the board for a first time:

This thing is TINY. I looked at the CAD beforehand and the comparisons to the Rio, but I don’t think they do it justice. It feels like I could pocket it and carry it as an EDC item image 1920×2550 416 KB

This thing is TINY. I looked at the CAD beforehand and the comparisons to the Rio, but I don’t think they do it justice. It feels like I could pocket it and carry it as an EDC item image 1920×2550 416 KB

image 1920×2550 416 KB

image 1920×2550 416 KB

I wish there was just one more USB mounting hole to allow for a capture mechanism for individual USB cables rather than one that encases all of them. Although, I’d imagine having to undo each bolt if you want to switch them around or change them out would get annoying pretty fast. Regardless, I want options!!!

I wish there was just one more USB mounting hole to allow for a capture mechanism for individual USB cables rather than one that encases all of them. Although, I’d imagine having to undo each bolt if you want to switch them around or change them out would get annoying pretty fast. Regardless, I want options!!!

One of the proposed changes is to replace the Weidmuller connectors on the power and CAN ports to Microfit+ and SL respectively. I have mixed feelings about this. On one hand, you have the ease of use and accessibility with the Weidmuller connectors since you really only need a wire stripper and something thin to press down the button. But on the other hand, you run the risk of having a poor connection due to a bad strip, bad engagement with the lever, etc. (which are all pretty frequent in my experience). Weidmuller connectors also wear down over time, with the button losing it’s spring force over frequent use. The SL and Microfit+ ports should fix these problems, but you also need the associate crimpers and connectors (which are EXPENSIVE, although I’ve seen cheap alternatives people have found here on CD )

One of the proposed changes is to replace the Weidmuller connectors on the power and CAN ports to Microfit+ and SL respectively. I have mixed feelings about this. On one hand, you have the ease of use and accessibility with the Weidmuller connectors since you really only need a wire stripper and something thin to press down the button. But on the other hand, you run the risk of having a poor connection due to a bad strip, bad engagement with the lever, etc. (which are all pretty frequent in my experience). Weidmuller connectors also wear down over time, with the button losing it’s spring force over frequent use. The SL and Microfit+ ports should fix these problems, but you also need the associate crimpers and connectors (which are EXPENSIVE, although I’ve seen cheap alternatives people have found here on CD )

So, it’s been talked about before in other SystemCore threads, but switching from a pull up resistor to a pull down wasn’t the best decision. It’s listed on the roadmap, but it looks like FIRST may make the Smart I/O pins configurable or pull-up compatible, so this probably won’t be a problem in the future?

Anyhow, KnightKrawler runs and have been running Allen Bradley right sight 42ef photoelectric sensors as beam breaks since 2016. We use them on Mayfly as a way to detect coral for both our L1 scoring system and stowing our arm+elevator once we have a coral. They can only work in a pull up configuration because they use an NPN transistor and do not have a comparator (at least that’s what we think, we’re still a little fuzzy on the issue and we only found out about this fact today!).

To temporarily fix this until we could figure out another solution, we put on our own weak pull up resistor. This worked, but we also knew how janky it was and the potential risks behind it. Here’s an image and very simplistic diagram of what we did (my electronical knowledge is pretty base level, so I apologize for any inaccuracies or misrepresentations) image 1323×599 52.8 KB image 1920×2560 397 KB

image 1323×599 52.8 KB

image 1323×599 52.8 KB

image 1920×2560 397 KB

image 1920×2560 397 KB

So, the day after, our mentor Ben remembered and reminded us that the pins are Smart I/O pins, meaning we can use analog control to read the sensor (AKA, programming issue!) This was a fairly simple process and worked well for us, despite our initial concerns about the speed of analog vs digital.

Plans for moving forward: I’d like to try out a few things on the SystemCore while we have it, including making a retention mechanism for the USB ports and running multiple CAN loops on the board. Stay tuned!

posts.name: Robertson Robotics
posts.cooked:
Kevin_Nguyen:

So, the day after, our mentor Ben remembered and reminded us that the pins are Smart I/O pins, meaning we can use analog control to read the sensor (AKA, programming issue!) This was a fairly simple process and worked well for us, despite our initial concerns about the speed of analog vs digital.

This is what our team has been doing with the Automation Direct QMRHD-0N-0A sensors on the roboRIO so that’s great to hear it still works well.
